question: What is the main reason the equator is warmer than the North Pole?

content.source_1: Because Earth is roughly spherical, sunlight strikes low latitudes at a higher angle, concentrating the same incoming energy onto a smaller surface area than at high latitudes where it is spread over a larger area.
content.source_2: When the Sun is low in the sky (typical of high latitudes), its rays travel through a longer path in the atmosphere, causing more scattering and absorption and reducing the solar energy that reaches the surface per unit area.
content.source_3: Fresh snow and sea ice have very high shortwave albedo (about 0.6–0.9), reflecting most incoming sunlight; open ocean and dark vegetation have much lower albedo (ocean ~0.06; forests ~0.1–0.2) and thus absorb far more sunlight.
content.source_4: The Arctic Ocean and Antarctica are covered by sea ice and snow for much of the year, giving the polar regions a much higher average surface reflectivity than low latitudes.
content.source_5: Equatorial regions are dominated by dark open ocean and dense vegetation, surfaces that, because of their low albedo, absorb a large fraction of incoming solar radiation.
content.source_6: Over a full year, all latitudes receive approximately the same total hours of daylight (about 12 hours per day on average).

answer: The equator receives more direct sunlight than the North Pole.
